This month, we especially remember and honor Black Americans who have served this nation and sacrificed their lives for liberty. 4/4

Sgt. Carney's legacy is enduring, but it wasn't always easy for Black soldiers to follow in his footsteps. Historians have long noted how racism impacted Medal of Honor recipients, as no soldiers in WWII were recognized until well after the war. /3

Born into slavery in 1840, Sgt. Carney escaped to Massachusetts when he was still a boy. When the Civil War broke out, he served in the 54th Massachusetts Infantry Regiment. There, his actions earned him a service member's highest distinction - the Medal of Honor. /2

This #BlackHistoryMonth, we pay tribute to the first Black Medal of Honor recipient - Sgt. William Carney. Earning his award for protecting the American flag in the Battle of Fort Wagner during the Civil War, he is among America's most selfless heroes. /1 https://www.militarytimes.com/military-honor/black-military-history/2018/02/06/william-h-carney-the-first-black-soldier-to-earn-the-medal-of-honor/

Last Congress, the Committee worked on more than 20 pieces of legislation that became law, including landmark bills to expand benefits to veterans exposed to Agent Orange and reduce veteran suicide.

This Congress, the Committee will ensure these laws are implemented efficiently. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Eu2k_RXXEAEKRQR.jpg

As the Committee with jurisdiction over @DeptVetAffairs, we will continue to hold VA accountable to ensure:

🔹 A strong & independent Office of Inspector General

🔹 Whistleblowers are protected

🔹 A streamlined & efficient debt relief process for veterans & their beneficiaries http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Eu2k-gHXAAYBnr7.jpg

The population of veterans who require long-term care bring unique challenges.

We must ensure VA continues to innovate when it comes to non-institutional care options that is beneficial for taxpayers and reflects the preferences of veterans and their families. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Eu2k96lXYAUbEX4.jpg

VA has several modernization efforts underway that will transform how it serves veterans – including the medical supply chain & electronic health record modernization project.

The Committee will work with VA to make additional progress & ensure these efforts are successful. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Eu2k9gWXYAAw-6B.jpg

At 2 mil. strong, women make up the largest & fastest growing cohort of the veteran population.

As the Deborah Sampson Act – the most comprehensive women veterans package in over a decade – moves toward implementation, we need to ensure a safe & welcoming VA for women veterans. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Eu2k9DIXEAIo1lr.jpg

After ending their service, many veterans continue their education to help further their careers.

The Committee will monitor the quality of education for student veterans using remote learning and ensure institutions can no longer defraud student veterans of their benefits. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Eu2k8WtXUAQoiPu.jpg

We must recognize toxic exposure as a cost of war.

This Congress, we will build upon the success of the #BlueWaterNavy Vietnam Veterans Act by working to ensure servicemembers exposed to toxic substances during their service can access the benefits and care they've earned. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Eu2k8ANXUAES_6k.jpg

Last Congress, the Committee advanced two bipartisan & bicameral bills to reduce veteran suicide.

But as long as 17 veterans die by suicide each day, our work to create meaningful solutions that help veterans in crisis – or prevent from falling into crisis – must continue. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Eu2k7loXMAENbW0.jpg

To build a more welcoming & effective VA, we must work to earn back the trust the it has lost.

This includes recognizing the diversity of our veteran population & ensuring all eligible veterans can access VA care & benefits – regardless of social or physical disparities. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Eu2k7LbXIAMwQHk.jpg

6/ I inherently trust the Biden team to pursue the right course here. But query whether reentering the JCPOA actually needs a new set of negotiations, or whether talks could be a trap, when a less complicated path to restarting the deal is right in front our eyes.
5/ "Compliance for compliance" is the right path. And the U.S. shouldn't be afraid of going first. If we release sanctions and Iran doesn't reciprocate, then we can always reapply sanctions.

4/ Going back to the negotiating table and demanding Iran do a broader agreement on nukes, missiles, terrorism, is a fool's errand. Pompeo tried to hold out for everything and failed miserably. Why choose to fail again, when a nuclear deal is there for taking now?

3/ Plus, so long as we continue Trump era sanctions, Iran will seek to destabilize the region, in Iran, Yemen, Syria, etc.

Neocons say we can't negotiate with Iran while they provoke, but that's their typical BS. We need de-escalation, and restarting the JCPOA does that.

2/ The Iran deal put the U.S./Europe/Russia/China all on the same side of Iran policy. Leaving the deal shattered that coalition. 

We can't make progress on Iran's missile program or terrorist funding without this team regrouping, and a quick reentry to the JCPOA does this.

The Iran nuclear deal's original terms made the world a safer place. That's why restarting the agreement through "compliance for compliance", rather than trying to hold out for a new/different deal (as Trump, Iran hawks wanted) is the best path.

Additionally, the installation in the early phases of the program was sometimes done without proper ventilation or attention to other structural concerns, leading to cases of mold or structural damage in certain homes.
